Key Arguments: The government and its bureaucrats are the biggest propagators of misinformation and disinformation, yet they are excluded from the legislation.
The legislation appears to be designed to suppress dissent against the government, removing free speech and the right to debate.
The definitions of misinformation and disinformation are misleading and have been used to suppress truths that later became accepted realities.
The legislation could lead to Orwellian censorship, eliminating the ability for citizens to access truth and protest government mistakes.
The bill could restrict Australians from accessing global information, causing serious harm.
The penalties for non-compliance are severe and unwarranted, aimed at preventing freedom of speech.
Main Themes: Government accountability and exclusion from the legislation
Suppression of free speech and dissent
Misleading definitions of misinformation and disinformation
Potential for censorship and control of information
Severe penalties as a deterrent to free speech
Notable Quotes: The biggest propagators of mis and disinformation over the last 3 years have been our Government and its bureaucrats.
This legislation appears to be designed to remove any sources of dissent against the Government in power, removing free speech and the right to debate.
The use of the words misinformation and disinformation are key to the sleight of hand in this legislation.
There has never been a time in history where those seeking to limit information or destroy history have been on the side of what is right.
These penalties are to prevent freedom of speech and the spread of truth that would undermine The Narrative.
